Introduction

Erythema multiforme (EM) is an acute, immune-mediated mucocutaneous condition characterized by the abrupt onset of erythematous macules, papules, and targetoid lesions.  It is commonly associated with infections (particularly herpes simplex virus [HSV]) and various medications.  The disease spectrum ranges from minor, localized cutaneous lesions to major, widespread skin disease with debilitating mucosal involvement and systemic symptoms.

Pathophysiology

EM is caused by a cell-mediated immune response, most commonly to antigens from HSV; it frequently appears several days to a few weeks after genital or orolabial HSV infection.  EM can also be triggered by other infections and medications (eg, sulfonamides, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs [NSAIDs]).

EM develops when circulating pathogens are phagocytosed by peripheral mononuclear cells and brought to the epidermis, where DNA fragments are transferred to keratinocytes via direct cell-to-cell spread (facilitated by upregulation of adhesion molecules).  Pathogen-specific cytotoxic T cells then recognize foreign antigens produced by keratinocytes and initiate an inflammatory cascade that results in epithelial damage.

Risk factors

  • Infections:
    • HSV (most common)
    • Mycoplasma pneumoniae
    • Fungal and bacterial infections
  • Medications:
    • Sulfonamides
    • Anticonvulsants
    • NSAIDs
    • Antibiotics (eg, penicillin, cephalosporins)
    • Other factors, including vaccinations, malignancies, and radiation therapy

Pathology

Histopathologic examination shows epidermal necrosis, vacuolar interface dermatitis, and a perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate (

image 1
).  The hallmark is necrotic keratinocytes in the epidermis, indicative of immune-mediated damage.  Subepidermal bullae formation and dermal edema may also occur.

Clinical presentation

EM presents with acute onset (3-5 days) of symmetrical, erythematous lesions.  Although the morphology varies from case to case, the appearance of lesions in any individual case is usually relatively uniform.  The classic lesions appear as small (<3 cm) targetoid lesions with distinct color zones (

image 2
):

  • A dusky center (often with a small bulla or crust)
  • A pale surrounding zone
  • A well-defined, erythematous border

The lesions predominantly involve the extremities, including the palms and soles, but may occur anywhere.  They are not typically painful, but moderate discomfort (eg, pruritus, burning sensation) may occur.  In many cases, skin lesions are preceded by a flu-like prodrome, manifesting with fever, malaise, and sore throat.

The severity of EM can be categorized as follows:

  • EM minor involves only the skin or causes only mild mucosal lesions.
  • EM major includes painful erosions and bullae affecting the oral, ocular, and genital mucosae, often with significant systemic symptoms (eg, fever, arthralgia).

Diagnosis

Diagnosis of EM is primarily clinical, based on acute onset of the distinctive target lesions.  A thorough history and physical examination may identify potential triggers.  Skin biopsy can confirm the diagnosis in atypical cases but is not always necessary.

Laboratory studies are not specific for EM diagnosis but can assess severity and identify possible triggers.  The following tests are often considered:

  • HSV PCR:  to detect active herpes simplex infection
  • Mycoplasma serology:  in suspected cases of Mycoplasma pneumoniaeâ€“associated EM
  • Complete blood count:  to assess for leukocytosis or anemia
  • Liver and renal function tests:  to evaluate systemic involvement, especially if medications are implicated

Imaging is not routinely required for the diagnosis of EM.  However, a chest x-ray may be indicated if there is suspicion of Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection.

Differential diagnosis

  • Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) (
    image 3
    ):  often present with broad areas of erythema with extensive epidermal sloughing, typically with severe mucosal involvement, whereas EM typically has more localized lesions.  The presence of widespread skin detachment (>10% of body surface area) and systemic symptoms such as high fever and malaise further differentiates SJS/TEN from EM.
  • Urticaria (
    image 4
    ):  presents with transient wheals that can appear similar to the erythematous lesions of EM.  However, urticarial lesions usually appear as circumscribed wheals and lack the central dusky zone typical of EM's target lesions.  Also, urticaria usually resolves within 24 hours, unlike the more persistent lesions of EM.
  • Bullous pemphigoid (
    image 5
    ):  characterized by large, tense, subepidermal bullae with erosions and sloughing.  Compared to EM, the bullae are typically much larger and not surrounded by targetoid erythema.  Histologically, pemphigoid is characterized by IgG and C3 deposition at the basement membrane (visible with immunofluorescent staining), distinguishing it from the necrotic keratinocytes seen in EM.
  • Viral exanthems (
    image 6
    ):  a variety of viruses and other infections can cause a diffuse maculopapular or vesicular rash, especially in children.  The clinical morphology of these rashes is variable, but most show significant involvement of the trunk and usually do not have a targetoid appearance.  A typical viral syndrome (eg, upper respiratory infection) may be associated.
  • Fixed drug eruption (
    image 7
    ):  manifests as recurrent lesions at the same site on reexposure to the drug, differentiating it from EM, which typically presents with new lesions at varying sites.  Lesions of fixed drug eruption are often solitary, are sharply demarcated, and may develop central blistering.
  • Erythema nodosum (
    image 8
    ):  presents with tender, erythematous nodules typically located on the anterior shins.  Unlike the targetoid lesions of EM, erythema nodosum lesions are more indurated, lack central clearing, and are often associated with systemic conditions such as sarcoidosis, infections, or medications.
  • Cutaneous small vessel vasculitis (leukocytoclastic vasculitis) (
    image 9
    ):  can be triggered by a variety of infections and medications and typically presents with painless, erythematous lesions predominantly on the extremities.  The classic, palpable, purpuric lesions are distinct from the targetoid lesions typical of EM, but biopsy may be needed in less typical cases.

Management

  • Identification and removal of triggers:  discontinuation of any suspected medications and treatment of underlying infection as appropriate.
  • Symptomatic treatment:
    • Topical corticosteroids (eg, betamethasone dipropionate) for cutaneous lesions
    • Systemic corticosteroids (eg, prednisone) for severe cases (eg, severe oral mucosal involvement), although their use remains controversial
    • Antihistamines for pruritus
    • Analgesics for pain management
  • Specific treatments:
    • Antiviral therapy (eg, acyclovir): episodic antiviral therapy has generally not been shown to be effective for acute EM.  However, continuous (suppressive) therapy may be beneficial for some patients with recurrent HSV-associated EM.
    • Antibiotics are indicated for EM associated with active Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection.

Prognosis and complications

EM is typically self-limiting, with lesions resolving within 2-6 weeks.  Recurrences are common, particularly with HSV-associated EM.  Prognosis is excellent for EM minor, whereas EM major may require significant supportive care and carries a risk of significant morbidity if mucosal involvement is severe.

Potential complications of EM include

  • Secondary infections:  due to skin barrier disruption
  • Ocular involvement:  can lead to conjunctivitis, uveitis, or corneal ulcers
  • Dehydration and nutritional deficiencies:  from extensive mucosal involvement

Summary

Erythema multiforme is an acute mucocutaneous condition with a characteristic clinical presentation.  Prompt recognition and management are essential to mitigate symptoms and address potential triggers.  Although the prognosis is generally favorable, recurrence is common, necessitating ongoing vigilance for potential precipitating factors.
